I dual boot. I normally run linux though.

item.title: Lawls! (edited)
item.dc:creator: @Exception Exception

@Exception wrote:

C# does have garbage collection, but if you use it in managed mode, the amount of havok you’d be able to wreak is rather limited compared to an unmanaged language.

item.title: Lawls! (edited)
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Iamadam: That will continue until the Threads reaches max Thread amount (and will of course break so it won’t run out of memory)… But all in all, looks nice anyway.

Not that I think you didn’t already know that, but anyway.

Read full topic

item.title: Lawls! (edited)
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

[code]public class FunThread implements Runnable {

public static void main(String args[]) {
new Thread(new FunThread()).start();
}

public void run() {
while (true) {
new Thread(new FunThread()).start();
}
}
}[/code]

Read full topic

As do I, do you use the Eclipse GCC plug too?

It’s too bad that sun doesn’t support 64-bit browser plugins(Until Java 1.7 release candidates). Used GCJ(IcedTea) but the lack of a security manager was worrisome, so 32-bit browsing I shall go.[/quote]Sure do

item.title: Lawls! (edited)
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

use: while (true) {…shit here…}

Don’t bother with native - if your hoping to consume all the mem/cpu on a system you can use java for the same task. Just set the memory limits to be higher than your swap and RAM size “-Xmx2000Mb” should do it. PS. if you want to corrupt memory try using the class called “Unsafe” in the sun package. You will probably have to download the source of the sun jdk but its the simplest way to find out how to access its functions. Then use the putInt functions of whatever with null objects and large integers to start writing data to random bits of memory. Have fun rebooting as your system crashes.

Read full topic

item.title: Lawls! (edited)
item.dc:creator: @meiscooldude meiscooldude
item.description:
@meiscooldude wrote:

assert meiscooldude(); public class Spam { public static void meiscooldude() { // Yeah it's possible in java to make an automated poster, but that's way too much work for a piece of sarcasm. Moparisthebest.smf.post("I make useless threads to bring attention to my mental shortcomings."); } }

Gee… Thanks…

Anyways… I know that " i " can go negative, so, I should actually use a boolean and a while loop. (if i wanted it to be inf.)

Also, If I really wanted to make this little program effective… I would do it in c++. (Since it does’nt have garbage collection and it is more native to windows… even though i use linux.)

Read full topic
